user_indicator: You are able to analyze your present system and derive continuous improvements from it.

incose_mappings.indicator: Uses analysis of a system functions and parts to predict resultant system behavior.
Identifies potential enterprise improvements to enable system development.

user_indicator: You are able to carry systemic thinking into the company and inspire others for it.

incose_mappings.indicator: Uses systems thinking to contribute to enterprise technology development activities.
Guides team systems thinking activities in order to ensure current activities align to purpose.

user_indicator: You are able to recognize the interrelationships of your system and its boundaries.

incose_mappings.indicator: Explains why it is important to recognise interactions among systems and their elements.
Identifies the context of a system from a range of view points including system boundaries and external interfaces.

user_indicator: You understand the interaction of the individual components that make up the system.

incose_mappings.indicator: Explains why it is important to recognise interactions among systems and their elements.
Identifies the interaction between humans and systems, and systems and systems.

user_indicator: You are able to identify, consider, and assess all lifecycle phases relevant to your scope.

incose_mappings.indicator: Identifies different life cycle types and summarizes the key characteristics of each.
Identifies the impact of failing to consider future life cycle stages in the current stage.

user_indicator: You are able to evaluate concepts regarding the consideration of all lifecycle phases.

incose_mappings.indicator: Explains why differing engineering approaches are required in different life cycle phases and provides examples.
Explains how different life cycle characteristics relate to the system life cycle.

user_indicator: You are able to identify the lifecycle phases of your system.

incose_mappings.indicator: Identifies different life cycle types and summarizes the key characteristics of each.
Describes the system life cycle in which they are working on their project.

user_indicator: You understand why and how all lifecycle phases need to be considered during development.

incose_mappings.indicator: Explains why selection of life cycle is important when developing a system solution.
Explains why differing engineering approaches are required in different life cycle phases and provides examples.

user_indicator: You are able to define your own system models for the relevant scope independently and can differentiate between cross-domain and domain-specific models.

incose_mappings.indicator: Defines appropriate representations of a system or system element.
Uses different types of models for different reasons.

user_indicator: You can set guidelines for necessary models and write guidelines for good modeling practices.

incose_mappings.indicator: Creates a governing process, plan, and associated tools for systems modeling and analysis in order to monitor and control systems modeling and analysis activities on a system or system element.
Advises stakeholders across the enterprise, on systems modeling and analysis.

user_indicator: You are familiar with the basics of modeling and its benefits.

incose_mappings.indicator: Explains why system representations are required and the benefits they can bring to developments.
Explains why the benefits of modeling can only be realized if choices made in defining the model are correct.

user_indicator: You understand how models support your work and are able to read simple models.

incose_mappings.indicator: Explains why system representations are required and the benefits they can bring to developments.
Explains the relevance of outputs from systems modeling and analysis, and how these relate to overall system development.

user_indicator: You are able to communicate constructively and efficiently while being empathetic towards your communication partner.

incose_mappings.indicator: Fosters positive relationships through effective communications.
Fosters trust through openness and transparency in communication.

user_indicator: You are able to sustain and fairly manage your relationships with colleagues and supervisors.

incose_mappings.indicator: Fosters positive relationships through effective communications.
Uses appropriate communications techniques to ensure positive relationships are maintained.

user_indicator: You are aware of the necessity of these competencies.

incose_mappings.indicator: Explains why there is a need for clear and concise communications.
Explains why systems engineers need to listen to stakeholders’ point of view.

user_indicator: You recognize and understand the relevance of this competency, especially in terms of its application in systems engineering.

incose_mappings.indicator: Explains why there is a need for clear and concise communications.
Explains why employing the appropriate means for communications is essential.

user_indicator: You are able to negotiate objectives with your team and find an efficient path to achieve them.

incose_mappings.indicator: Fosters a collaborative approach in their Systems Engineering leadership activities.
Uses team and project to guide direction, thinking strategically, holistically, and systemically when performing own Systems Engineering leadership activities.

user_indicator: You are able to strategically develop team members so that they evolve in their problem-solving capabilities.

incose_mappings.indicator: Fosters the empowerment of team members, by supporting, facilitating, promoting, giving ownership, and supporting them in their endeavors.
Develops strategies for leadership activities or the resolution of team issues, using creativity and innovation.

user_indicator: You are aware of the necessity of leadership competencies.

incose_mappings.indicator: Explains the role of technical leadership within Systems Engineering.
Explains why understanding the strategy is central to Systems Engineering leadership.

user_indicator: You understand the relevance of defining objectives for a system and can articulate these objectives clearly to the entire team.

incose_mappings.indicator: Develops technical vision for a project team, influencing and integrating the viewpoints of others in order to gain acceptance.
Identifies a leadership strategy to support of project goals, changing as necessary, to ensure success.

user_indicator: You are able to define a project mandate, establish conditions, create complex project plans, and produce meaningful reports.

incose_mappings.indicator: Develops inputs to a project management plan for a complete project beyond those required for Systems Engineering planning to support wider project or business project management.
Prepares Systems Engineering Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) information for project management in support of their creation of a wider project WBS.

user_indicator: You are skilled in communicating with stakeholders.

incose_mappings.indicator: Guides and actively coordinates complex or challenging relationships with key stakeholders affecting Systems Engineering.
Communicates own knowledge and experience in the integration of project management with Systems Engineering, in order to improve Systems Engineering best practice beyond the enterprise boundary.

user_indicator: You can successfully communicate reports, plans, and mandates to all stakeholders.

incose_mappings.indicator: Describes the key interfaces between project management stakeholders within the enterprise and the project team.
Prepares inputs to work products which interface to project management stakeholders to ensure Systems Engineering work aligns with wider project management activities.

user_indicator: You can identify inadequacies in the process and suggest improvements.

incose_mappings.indicator: Identifies potential issues with interfacing work products received from project management Stakeholders or produced by Systems Engineering for project management stakeholders taking appropriate action.
Identifies Systems Engineering tasks ensuring that these tasks integrate successfully with project management activities.

user_indicator: You are familiar with common project management methods.

incose_mappings.indicator: Explains the meaning of commonly used project management terms and applicable standards.
Explains the role the project management function plays in developing a successful system product or service.

user_indicator: You are able to identify your activities within a project plan.

incose_mappings.indicator: Identifies Systems Engineering tasks ensuring that these tasks integrate successfully with project management activities.
Identifies activities required to ensure integration of project management planning and estimating with Systems Engineering planning and estimating.

user_indicator: You can create relevant project plans and generate corresponding status reports independently.

incose_mappings.indicator: Develops inputs to a project management plan for a complete project beyond those required for Systems Engineering planning to support wider project or business project management.
Prepares inputs to work products which interface to project management stakeholders to ensure Systems Engineering work aligns with wider project management activities.

user_indicator: You understand the project mandate and can contextualize project management within systems engineering.

incose_mappings.indicator: Explains the role the project management function plays in developing a successful system product or service.
Describes the differences between performing project management and Systems Engineering management on that project.

user_indicator: You are able to prepare or make decisions for your relevant scopes and document them accordingly. You can apply decision support methods, such as utility analysis.

incose_mappings.indicator: Prepares information in support of decision trade studies.
Identifies potential decision criteria and performance parameters for consideration.

user_indicator: You can evaluate decisions and are able to define and establish overarching decision-making bodies. You can define good guidelines for making decisions.

incose_mappings.indicator: Creates a strategy for decision management on a project to support SE project and wider enterprise needs.
Develops governing decision management plans, processes, and appropriate tools and uses these to control and monitor decision management activities.

user_indicator: You are aware of the main decision-making bodies and understand how decisions are made.

incose_mappings.indicator: Explains why there is a need to select a preferred solution.
Explains how uncertainty impacts on decision-making.

user_indicator: You understand decision support methods and know which decisions you can make yourself and which are made by committees.

incose_mappings.indicator: Identifies the Systems Engineering situations where a structured decision is, and is not, appropriate.
Explains how to frame, tailor, and structure a decision including its objectives and measures and outlines the key characteristics of a structured decision-making approach.

user_indicator: You are able to define storage structures and documentation guidelines for projects, and can provide relevant information at the right place.

incose_mappings.indicator: Creates a strategy for Information Management on a project to support SE project and wider enterprise needs.
Selects and implements information management solutions consistent with project security and privacy requirements, data rights, and information management standards.

user_indicator: You can define a comprehensive information management process.

incose_mappings.indicator: Creates a strategy for Information Management on a project to support SE project and wider enterprise needs.
Creates enterprise-level policies, procedures, guidance, and best practice for information management, including associated tools.

user_indicator: You are aware of the benefits of established information and knowledge management.

incose_mappings.indicator: Describes various types of information required to be managed in support of Systems Engineering activities and provides examples.
Describes various types of information assets that may need to be managed within a project or system.

user_indicator: You understand the key platforms for knowledge transfer and know which information needs to be shared with whom.

incose_mappings.indicator: Identifies valid sources of information and associated authorities on a project.
Creates a strategy for Information Management on a project to support SE project and wider enterprise needs.

user_indicator: You can define sensible configuration items and recognize those relevant to you.

incose_mappings.indicator: Describes the need to identify configuration items and why this is done.
Describes the key characteristics of a configuration item (CI) including how configuration items are selected and controlled.

user_indicator: You are capable of using tools to define configuration items and create configurations for your scopes.

incose_mappings.indicator: Describes the key characteristics of a configuration item (CI) including how configuration items are selected and controlled.
Describes the need to identify configuration items and why this is done.

user_indicator: You are able to recognize all relevant configuration items and create a comprehensive configuration across all items.

incose_mappings.indicator: Describes the need to identify configuration items and why this is done.
Identifies selection of configuration items and associated documentation by working with design teams justifying the decisions reached.

user_indicator: You can identify improvements, propose solutions, and assist others in configuration management.

incose_mappings.indicator: Guides new or supervised practitioners in configuration management to develop their knowledge, abilities, skills, or associated behaviors.
Creates a strategy for Configuration Management on a project to support SE project and wider enterprise needs.

user_indicator: You are aware of the necessity of configuration management.

incose_mappings.indicator: Explains why the integrity of the design needs to be maintained and how configuration management supports this.
Describes the key characteristics of a configuration item (CI) including how configuration items are selected and controlled.

user_indicator: You know which tools are used to create configurations.

incose_mappings.indicator: Follows a governing configuration and change management process and appropriate tools to plan and control their own activities relating to maintaining design integrity.
Lists key activities performed as part of configuration management and can outline the key activities involved in each.

user_indicator: You are able to use the tools necessary to create configurations for your scopes.

incose_mappings.indicator: Follows a governing configuration and change management process and appropriate tools to plan and control their own activities relating to maintaining design integrity.

Creates governing configuration and change management plans, processes, and appropriate tools, and uses these to control and monitor design integrity during the full life cycle of a project or system.

user_indicator: You understand the process of defining configuration items and can identify those relevant to you.

incose_mappings.indicator: Describes the need to identify configuration items and why this is done.
Describes the key characteristics of a configuration item (CI) including how configuration items are selected and controlled.

user_indicator: You can independently identify sources of requirements, derive, write, and document requirements in documents or models, link, derive, and analyze them.

incose_mappings.indicator: Creates a strategy for requirements definition on a project to support SE project and wider enterprise needs.
Develops good quality, consistent requirements.

user_indicator: You can independently document, link, and analyze requirement documents or models. You can create and analyze context descriptions and interface specifications.

incose_mappings.indicator: Creates a strategy for requirements definition on a project to support SE project and wider enterprise needs.
Creates a governing process, plan, and associated tools for Requirements Definition, which reflect project and business strategy.

user_indicator: You can create context and interface descriptions and discuss these with stakeholders.

incose_mappings.indicator: Creates a strategy for requirements definition on a project to support SE project and wider enterprise needs.
Creates a governing process, plan, and associated tools for Requirements Definition, which reflect project and business strategy.

user_indicator: You are able to recognize deficiencies in the process and develop suggestions for improvement.

incose_mappings.indicator: Creates a strategy for requirements definition on a project to support SE project and wider enterprise needs.
Creates a governing process, plan, and associated tools for Requirements Definition, which reflect project and business strategy.

user_indicator: You are able to distinguish between needs, stakeholder requirements, system requirements, and system element requirements. You understand the importance of traceability and why tools are necessary for it.

incose_mappings.indicator: Defines (or maintains) requirements traceability information.
Creates a system to support requirements management and traceability.

user_indicator: You know the basic process of requirement management including identifying, formulating, deriving and analyzing requirements.

incose_mappings.indicator: Describes the characteristics of good quality requirements and provides examples.
Explains why managing requirements throughout the life cycle is important.

user_indicator: You understand how to identify sources of requirements, derive and write them. You know the different types and levels of requirements.

incose_mappings.indicator: Describes different types of requirements and constraints that may be placed on a system.
Describes the characteristics of good quality requirements and provides examples.

user_indicator: You can read requirement documents or models (links, etc.). You can read and understand context descriptions and interface specifications.

incose_mappings.indicator: Describes different types of requirements and constraints that may be placed on a system.
Describes the characteristics of good quality requirements and provides examples.

user_indicator: You can create architectural models of average complexity, ensuring the information is reproducible and aligned with the methodology and modeling language.

incose_mappings.indicator: Uses analysis techniques or principles used to support an architectural design process.
Produces traceability information linking differing architectural design solutions to requirements.

user_indicator: You know the relevant process steps for architectural models, where their inputs come from, and the outputs they produce within the development process.

incose_mappings.indicator: Describes the process and key artifacts of functional analysis.
Uses analysis techniques or principles used to support an architectural design process.

user_indicator: You are capable of creating and managing highly complex models, recognizing deficiencies in the method or modeling language, and suggesting improvements.

incose_mappings.indicator: Creates alternative architectural designs traceable to the requirements to demonstrate different approaches to the solution.
Uses different techniques to develop architectural solutions.

user_indicator: You can identify shortcomings in the process and develop suggestions for improvement.

incose_mappings.indicator: Uses analysis techniques or principles used to support an architectural design process.
Compares the characteristics of different concepts to determine their strengths and weaknesses.

user_indicator: You know that there is a dedicated methodology and modeling language for architectural modeling.

incose_mappings.indicator: Describes the principles of architectural design and its role within the life cycle.
Describes different types of architecture and provides examples.

user_indicator: You are aware of the purpose of architectural models and can broadly categorize them in the development process.

incose_mappings.indicator: Describes the principles of architectural design and its role within the life cycle.
Describes different types of architecture and provides examples.

user_indicator: You can read architectural models and extract relevant information from them.

incose_mappings.indicator: Uses analysis techniques or principles used to support an architectural design process.
Prepares architectural design work products (or parts thereof) traceable to the requirements.

user_indicator: You understand why architectural models are relevant as inputs and outputs of the development process.

incose_mappings.indicator: Explains why architectural decisions can constrain and limit future use and evolution and provides examples.
Explains why there is a need for functional models of the system.

user_indicator: You can create test plans and are capable of conducting and documenting tests and simulations.

incose_mappings.indicator: Prepares inputs to verification plans.
Prepares verification plans for smaller projects.

user_indicator: You are able to independently and proactively set up a testing strategy and an experimental plan. Based on requirements and verification/validation criteria, you can derive necessary test cases and orchestrate and document the tests and simulations.

incose_mappings.indicator: Creates a strategy for system verification on a project to support SE project and wider enterprise needs.
Creates a strategy for system validation on a project to support SE project and wider enterprise needs.

user_indicator: You are aware of the objectives of verification and validation and know various types and approaches of V&V.

incose_mappings.indicator: Explains what verification is, the purpose of verification, and why verification against the system requirements is important.
Explains what validation is, the purpose of validation, and why validation is important.

user_indicator: You can read and understand test plans, test cases, and results.

incose_mappings.indicator: Collates evidence during integration in support of downstream test and acceptance activities.
Prepares evidence obtained during integration in support of downstream test and acceptance activities.

user_indicator: You can execute the operation, service, and maintenance phases and identify improvements for future projects.

incose_mappings.indicator: Uses a governing process and appropriate tools to plan and control their own operations and support activities.
Identifies operational data in order to assess system performance.

user_indicator: You are able to define organizational processes for operation, maintenance, and servicing.

incose_mappings.indicator: Creates a strategy for system utilization and support, which reflects wider project and business strategies.
Creates a governing process, plan, and associated tools for system utilization and support, which reflect wider project and business plans.

user_indicator: You are familiar with the stages of operation, service, and maintenance phases. You understand these are considered during development and involve activities in each phase.

incose_mappings.indicator: Explains why a system needs to be supported during operation.
Explains why it is necessary to address failures, parts obsolescence, and evolving user requirements during system operation.

user_indicator: You understand how the operation, service, and maintenance phases are integrated into the development. You are able to list the activities required throughout the lifecycle.

incose_mappings.indicator: Explains why it is necessary to address failures, parts obsolescence, and evolving user requirements during system operation.
Identifies operational data in order to assess system performance.
